Linear programming and the intersection of free subgroups in free products of groups

S. V. Ivanov Department of Mathematics
University of Illinois
Urbana
IL 61801
U.S.A. ivanov@illinois.edu
Abstract.

We study the intersection of finitely generated factor-free subgroups of free products of groups by utilizing the method of linear programming. For example, we prove that if H1 is a finitely generated factor-free noncyclic subgroup of the free product G1*G2 of two finite groups G1, G2, then the Walter Neumann coefficient Ïƒâ¢(H1) of H1 is rational and can be computed. This coefficient Ïƒâ¢(H1) is the minimal positive real number such that, for every finitely generated factor-free subgroup H2 of G1*G2, it is true that rÂ¯â¢(H1,H2)â‰¤Ïƒâ¢(H1)â¢rÂ¯â¢(H1)â¢rÂ¯â¢(H2), where rÂ¯â¢(H)=maxâ¡(râ¢(H)-1,0) is reduced rank of H, râ¢(H) is rank of H, and rÂ¯â¢(H1,H2) is reduced rank of a generalized intersection of H1,H2.

Key words and phrases:
Free products of groups, free and factor-free subgroups, rank of intersection of factor-free subgroups, linear programming.

Primary 20E06, 20E07, 20F65, 90C90.

Let q*=q*(GÎ±,Î±âˆˆI) denote the minimum of orders >2 of finite subgroups of groups GÎ±, Î±âˆˆI, and let q*:=âˆ if there are no such subgroups. It is clear that either q* is an odd prime or q*âˆˆ{4,âˆ}. If q*=âˆ, define q*q*-2:=1. Dicks and the author [6] proved that if H1, H2 are finitely generated factor-free subgroups of â„±, then

This conjecture can be regarded as a far reaching generalization of the Hanna Neumann conjecture [23] on rank of the intersection of subgroups in free groups. Recall that the Hanna Neumann conjecture [23] claims that if H1, H2 are finitely generated subgroups of a free group, then rÂ¯â¢(H1âˆ©H2)â‰¤rÂ¯â¢(H1)â¢rÂ¯â¢(H2). For more discussion, partial results and proofs of this conjecture the reader is referred to [4], [5], [8], [18], [22], [24], [26], [27].

The conjecture (1.2) is established by Dicks and the author [7] in the case when â„± is the free product of two groups of order 3 in which case q*=3 and (1.2) turns into

Another special case in which the conjecture (1.2) is known to be true is the case when â„± is the free product of infinite cyclic groups, i.e., â„± is a free group, as follows from Friedmanâ€™s [8] and Mineyevâ€™s [22] proofs of the Hanna Neumann conjecture, see also Dicksâ€™s proof [5]. rÂ¯â¢(H1âˆ©H2)â‰¤rÂ¯â¢(H1)â¢rÂ¯â¢(H2). (1.3)

More generally, the inequality (1.3) also holds in the case when â„± is the free product of right orderable groups as follows from results of AntolÃ­n, Martino, and Schwabrow [1], see also [18]. We mention that it follows from results of [6] that the conjectured inequality (1.2) is sharp and may not be improved.

In an attempt to improve on the bound (1.1) in a special case, Dicks and the author [7] showed that

rÂ¯â¢(H1âˆ©H2)â‰¤(2-(4+2â¢3)â¢p(2â¢p-3+3)2)â‹…pp-2â¢rÂ¯â¢(H1)â¢rÂ¯â¢(H2) (1.4)

Note that for p=3 the inequality (1.4) yields the conjectured inequality (1.2). However, for prime pâ‰¥5, the problem whether the inequality (1.2) holds for the free product of two cyclic groups of order p remains open and seems to be the most basic and appealing case of the conjecture (1.2) for groups with torsion. In this connection, we remark that the ideas of articles [1], [5], [8], [22], do not look to be applicable to the case of free products with torsion and shed no light on the conjecture (1.2) for free products of groups with torsion, especially, for free products of finite groups.

In this article, however, we will not attempt to prove or improve on any upper bounds. Instead, we will look at generalized intersections of finitely generated factor-free subgroups in free products of groups from a disparate standpoint and prove results of quite different flavor by utilizing the method of linear programming.

First we recall a stronger version of the conjecture (1.2) that generalizes the strengthened Hanna Neumann conjecture which was put forward by Walter Neumann [24] for subgroups of free groups. The article is structured as follows. Proof.

The proof is based on Stallingsâ€™s folding techniques and is somewhat analogous to the proof of van Kampen lemma for diagrams over free products of groups, see [21] (in fact, it is simpler because foldings need not preserve the property of being planar for diagrams).

Let HV=âŸ¨V1,â€¦,VkâŸ© be a subgroup of â„±, generated by some words V1,â€¦,Vk over ğ’œ. Without loss of generality we can assume that V1,â€¦,Vk are reduced words. We distinguish o as the base vertex of ~â¢Î¨ and call o primary, the vertices adjacent to o are called secondary vertices and so on. where bi,j is an element of the group GÎ±â¢(i,j).

Clearly, Ï†â¢(pi)â¢=0â¢Vi in â„± for all i=1,â€¦,k.

It is also clear that ~â¢Î¨=~â¢Î¨o is a finite connected ğ’œ-graph with the base vertex o that has the following property.

  • (Q)

    A word Wâˆˆâ„± belongs to H if and only if there is a path p in ~â¢Î¨o such that p-=p+=o and Ï†â¢(p)â¢=0â¢W.

However, ~â¢Î¨o need not be irreducible and we will do foldings of edges in ~â¢Î¨o which preserve property (Q) and which are aimed to achieve properties (P1)â€“(P2).

Assume that property (P1) fails for edges e,f with e-=f-âˆˆVPâ¢~â¢Î¨o so that e+â‰ f+ and Î¸â¢(e)=Î¸â¢(f). If property (P2) fails for edges e,f and Ï†â¢(e)=Ï†â¢(f) in GÎ¸â¢(e), then we identify the edges e,f. Note property (Q) still holds ((P1) might fail) and the number |Eâ¢~â¢Î¨o| decreases.

Thus, by induction on |Eâ¢~â¢Î¨o| in polynomially many (relative to âˆ‘i=1k|Vi|) steps as described above, we either establish that the subgroup HV is not factor-free or construct an irreducible ğ’œ-graph Î¨o with property (Q).

4. Utilizing Linear and Linear Semi-infinite Programming
